channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Senate approves legislation to end shutdown. And, where climate change efforts stand
item.description: The House returns to vote on a bipartisan bill that could end the government shutdown. And, at the COP30, data show the world is still far from meeting its climate goals.
item.content:encoded:
The House returns to vote on a bipartisan bill that could end the government shutdown. And, at the COP30, data show the world is still far from meeting its climate goals.

(Image credit: Anna Rose Layden)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: 9 strategies to find free or low-cost food when money is tight
item.description: Kevin Curry, a food influencer and a former SNAP recipient, explains where SNAP recipients can get the most up-to-date information on their benefits, and how anyone can find free or affordable food.
item.content:encoded:
Kevin Curry, a food influencer and a former SNAP recipient, explains where SNAP recipients can get the most up-to-date information on their benefits, and how anyone can find free or affordable food. 

(Image credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Bloomberg)
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra

item.title: I'm pregnant but my doctor won't see me before 9 weeks. Why not? Is it OK to wait?
item.description: A pregnancy test can tell you that you're expecting as early as 4 weeks, but most doctors won't see you for another month. Many women want care sooner. Why's it so hard to get and what can you do?
item.content:encoded: A pregnancy test can tell you that you're expecting as early as 4 weeks, but most doctors won't see you for another month. Many women want care sooner. Why's it so hard to get and what can you do?
item.dc:creator: Mara Gordon

item.title: How to avoid 'The Winner's Curse'
item.description: A new book by the Nobel-winning pioneer of behavioral economics offers some advice we can all use.
item.content:encoded: A new book by the Nobel-winning pioneer of behavioral economics offers some advice we can all use.
item.dc:creator: Greg Rosalsky

item.title: A suicide bomber targets an Islamabad court, killing 12 people and wounding 27
item.description: No group immediately claimed responsibility for the explosion, which also wounded at least 27 people, but Pakistan has struggled over the past months with a resurgent Pakistani Taliban.
item.content:encoded:
No group immediately claimed responsibility for the explosion, which also wounded at least 27 people, but Pakistan has struggled over the past months with a resurgent Pakistani Taliban.

(Image credit: Mohammad Yousuf)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Trump floats tariff 'dividends' even while plan shows major flaws
item.description: President Trump says the government will distribute checks to Americans from tariff revenue. Here's what that could mean.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump says the government will distribute checks to Americans from tariff revenue. Here's what that could mean.

(Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kurtzleben

item.title: 'No turning back': More and more Ukrainian women join the army to fight Russia
item.description: An increasing number of women are joining the Ukrainian military, with thousands serving in front line roles, as Russia's war on Ukraine nears its fourth year — with no peace in sight.
item.content:encoded:
An increasing number of women are joining the Ukrainian military, with thousands serving in front line roles, as Russia's war on Ukraine nears its fourth year — with no peace in sight.

(Image credit: Anton Shtuka for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: Sen. Fetterman slams Democrats for shutting down government
item.description: Sen. John Fetterman (D-Pa.) has a reputation for going against his party and he's been doing so by voting to reopen the government. He spoke to NPR Monday ahead of his new book release, "Unfettered."
item.content:encoded:
Sen. John Fetterman (D-Pa.) has a reputation for going against his party and he's been doing so by voting to reopen the government. He spoke to NPR Monday ahead of his new book release, "Unfettered."

(Image credit: Elizabeth Gillis)
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow

item.title: Climate negotiations have started. Here's how far countries need to go
item.description: Nations have begun climate negotiations at the COP30 summit in Brazil. Studies show the world is not on track to avoid the most damaging impacts of climate change.
item.content:encoded: Nations have begun climate negotiations at the COP30 summit in Brazil. Studies show the world is not on track to avoid the most damaging impacts of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sommer

item.title: Is hormone therapy for menopause right for you? 6 things to know
item.description: The science around hormone therapy to treat menopause has changed a lot since the FDA issued warning labels 20 years ago. Now the labels are being removed, here are 6 things to consider.
item.content:encoded:
The science around hormone therapy to treat menopause has changed a lot since the FDA issued warning labels 20 years ago. Now the labels are being removed, here are 6 things to consider.

(Image credit: MStudioImages)
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey
